thread.title: Liverpool flop Iago Aspas is making sure his career will not be defined by THAT corner
thread.title_full: Liverpool flop Iago Aspas is making sure his career will not be defined by THAT corner

author: mirror
title: Liverpool flop Iago Aspas is making sure his career will not be defined by THAT corner
text:
Sport Liverpool flop Iago Aspas is making sure his career will not be defined by THAT corner The striker has 13 goals in his last 13 appearances, including a strike in Real Madrid's first home defeat for 11 months on Wednesday Share Aspas celebrates his goal against Real Madrid (Photo: Rex Features) Share Get Liverpool FC   Thank you for subscribing!   
Rarely has a player's career at a club been so defined by one moment, let alone that moment being a corner, than Iago Aspas's one fateful season at Liverpool. 
The Kop end at Anfield on April 27, 2014, was meant to witness Liverpool's relentless charge to a first league title in 24 years. 
Instead, they saw Steven Gerrard slip, a classic Jose Mourinho defensive rearguard action from Chelsea and Liverpool's title dreams dashed. 
However, if Gerrard could be pardoned as a living legend, then Aspas's decision to play a corner along the ground only to a grateful Willian just before he scored Chelsea's second with Liverpool pressing for an equaliser saw the Spaniard ridiculed and quickly exiled from Anfield. 
Now, back at home at Celta Vigo, the 29-year-old is outgunning the likes Neymar, Antoine Griezmann and Karim Benzema as one of La Liga's hottest strikers. Aspas has 13 goals in his last 13 appearances (Photo: REUTERS) The Spaniard scored against England at Wembley (Photo: Reuters / Eddie Keogh) 
Aspas scored the opener and set up the winner for Jonny as Celta inflicted Real Madrid's first home defeat for 11 months on Wednesday and Celta's first victory at the Bernabeu for a decade in a 2-1 win. 
The fact the Real slumped to a second consecutive defeat after a Spanish record 40-game unbeaten run in all competitions shocked many. 
But that it was Celta and Aspas in particular that caused the damage was of little surprise to those who have watched the rebirth of the striker thanks to a perfect communion between player and club over the past two seasons. 
Aspas has now scored 13 goals in his last 13 appearances in La Liga, Copa del Rey and Europa League. 
Amidst that run he also showed he can perform on English soil by scoring on his Spain debut in a 2-2 draw at Wembley in November. 
Meanwhile, victory at the Bernabeu was Celta's sixth in a row. Aspas struggled at Liverpool (Photo: Getty) He is remembered for one fateful corner against Chelsea (Photo: Getty) 
The turnaround in Aspas's fortunes is not simply thanks to a return to Spain. 
After leaving Liverpool he spent a largely frustrating year on loan at Sevilla. 
Having watched on as Daniel Sturridge, Luis Suarez and Raheem Sterling tore Premier League defences apart in 2013/14, Aspas was primarily a spectator the following season as Carlos Bacca and Kevin Gameiro carried Sevilla to another Europa League. 
Aspas needed a home, and found one back at home. The club he joined as a kid, has supported ever since and, with hindsight, probably should never have left. 
Rather than feeling jilted, he was received back at Celta as a hero. 
He returned for half the price he left and with the money they got for him they signed Nolito before cashing in too when he left for Manchester City in the summer. Aspas celebrates a goal against Barcelona in October (Photo: Getty) Read More Real Madrid 1-2 Celta Vigo: Iago Aspas ruins Cristiano Ronaldo's first Cup game in two years - 5 things we learned 
Aspas had saved Celta in their toughest moments, now they were saving him. 
He scored twice on debut to prevent them potentially dropping into the Spain's regional third tier, got them promoted three years later and then top scored to stop them being relegated the following season before his move to Liverpool. 
His love for the club is so real he once joked that much less play for Galician rivals Deportivo la Coruna, he wouldn't even date a girl from A Coruna. 
Back where he feels loved, Aspas has taken Celta to the next level even without Nolito to share the goalscoring burden. 
When Barcelona visited Balaidos as all-conquering treble winners in September 2015, Aspas tore them to shreds - scoring twice in a 4-1 rout. Aspas battles Neymar (Photo: Getty) 
It took 13 months for Barca to concede four in a game again and again it was an Aspas-inspired Celta who did it in a thrilling 4-3 win earlier this season. 
Celta are riding the crest of a wave not just due to Aspas's goals, but also in large part to Eduardo Berizzo's cunning management. 
They face Shakhtar Donetsk in the last 32 of the Europa League in their first European campaign for a decade and will make the Cup semi-finals if they can finish the job in the second leg of their tie against Madrid next week. 
Three-time runners-up in the Copa del Rey, Celta have never won a major trophy. 
If they were to finally win it thanks to the goals of Balaidos' prodigal son, even the most hardened cynic would fail to be enchanted by the romance of the Cup. poll loading Should Liverpool have kept faith with Iago Aspas? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
